agent_utterance: Right after your next meal, take 2 minutes to jot a quick note: what you ate, how full you felt on a 0–5 scale, and one trigger you noticed (like stress or evening cues). Keep it brief and nonjudgmental. This tiny post-meal check-in helps you see patterns and makes it easier to nudge future choices toward your goal.
agent_monologue: I’m providing a concise rationale: this user benefits from a small, structured post-meal check-in to bridge intention and action, leveraging their preference for structure and sensitivity to stress. The suggestion stays simple and nonjudgmental to reduce resistance and support steady progress toward the target behavior.
user_utterance: Okay, I’ll do the quick post-meal check-in. I just finished lunch: a quinoa bowl with roasted veggies and grilled chicken, plus a small yogurt and an apple. I felt about 4/5 full after finishing. Trigger was work stress, so I paused and took a breath before deciding whether to have more. Portions felt reasonable and I kept things steady today.
